data.title: Library Guides at University of Missouri Libraries
data.meta_description: Links to government publications which show consumer prices for common household items or
data.text:
Wages in KOREA, 1930s

Note: Between 1910 and 1945, the Korean peninsula was under Japanese occupation and was known as Chosen.

NEW CAR PRICES

New Chevrolet car prices, 1930-1939

Prices on p. 6; full page images and model descriptions on pp. 14-58 of source.

Automobile prices, 1934

1938 car ad

from Collier's Magazine

Source: U.S. National Recovery Admin. rpt., pp. 5-11.

New cars - Price trends, 1929-1933

Source: Automobile facts and figures, 1934 edition, p. 74.

Buick prices, 1936. Source: Congressional report.

Packard prices, 1936. Source: Congressional report.

Automobile prices and quality in Consumers Union Reports:

1936 car prices in June 1936 issue pp. 3-10.

1937 car prices in Nov 1936 issue, pp. 13-15.

NOTE: Ford, Chrysler and General Motors (producer of Chevrolet) represented 91% of all new car registrations in 1934. Source: The Price of automobiles, U.S. National Recovery Administration, pp. 48-49. See graphical depiction of car sales by make in 1937.

USED CAR PRICES

NOTE: "In 1933, for every 100 new cars sold, 178 used cars were sold" (Source: The Price of Automobiles, U.S. National Recovery Administration, p. 10).

Used car prices by age, make and model - 1938

Shows retail sales value in 1938 for used 4-door sedans manufactured 1933-1937. Location: Cleveland OH. See table 10, pp. 61-68 of source.

Used car values, 1930

Covers Hudson and Packard. Source: Appraisers and assessors manual, p. 478.

Used car prices in 1936

Covers 1931-1935 models. Source: Consumer Union reports, July 1936.

Used car price modeling, 1938

"How much to pay for a used car" in How to buy a used car, pp. 24-26.

PARTS and SUPPLIES

Auto supply prices paid by farmers, 1910-1960

Motor oil, antifreeze, tires, spark plugs, etc. Source: USDA

Tire prices in Consumer Union reports magazine, Sep 1936, p. 11

Interesting facts:

In 1929-1930, 12% of people aged 18-21 were enrolled in college.

In 1939-1940, 15% of people aged 18-21 were enrolled in college.

NOTABLE FACT: Consumer Reports found in 1936 that men's shirts lasted only about 20-26 commercial washings before degrading (source).

NOTE: In 1930, more farm families had a telephone (34%) than a radio (21%). Source

"Money disbursement" is the measurement of how much money people make as well as how they spend that money.

In addition to the links below, we recommend the book America's Capacity to Consume, published in 1934 by the Brookings Institution. It reports personal and household income as well as consumer expenditures in the late 1920s and early 1930s.

"75 Years of American Finance: A Graphic Presentation 1861-1935" (with 1936-1938 supplement)

Source: Federal Reserve Bank of Saint Louis.
